thread.title: Growth 'remains below its long-run average', John Fraser says
thread.title_full: Growth 'remains below its long-run average', John Fraser says | afr.com

author: Jacob Greber
title: Growth 'remains below its long-run average', John Fraser says
text:
Treasury secretary John Fraser: "While growth in Australia may be stronger relative to that of many other advanced economies, it remains below its long-run average." Sean Davey Share on twitter by Jacob Greber Australia cannot afford to rely on the Asia-Pacific region for all its economic growth, said Treasury secretary John Fraser. He was appealing for the private sector to escalate its involvement in infrastructure projects, particularly across the nation's north.
In a speech that echoed warnings by Reserve Bank of Australia governor Glenn Stevens that the economy's potential growth rate may have fallen, Mr Fraser indicated the need for a pipeline of good projects was becoming critical.
"While growth in Australia may be stronger relative to that of many other advanced economies, it remains below its long-run average," he told a function in Melbourne on Monday.
He cautioned that while Europe has drawn a lot of attention in recent months, Australians need to keep close watch on the outlook across their own region.
"You might think this is an unusual statement to make, given that the region will remain the fastest-growing in the immediate-term at least," he said. "But growth has started to slow in some of the major economies in the region.
"That is why we can't put all of our eggs in the 'Asia-Pacific basket'.
